Here's an updated version of your code:","labels":["Incorrect (Factual)"]},{"start":512,"end":1118,"text":"```powershell\\nfunction Get-UserNameSIDfromAD {\\nparam(\\n[string] $LoginName\\n)\\n\\n[string] $domain\\n[string] $username\\n\\n$domain, $username = $LoginName.split('\\')\\n\\n$w32usracc = Get-CimInstance -ClassName win32_useraccount -Filter \"Name='$username' and Domain='$domain'\" | Select-Object -Property SID\\n\\n$res = [pscustomobject] @{\\nID = 1\\nSqlSID = $w32usracc.SID\\nMessage = 'OK'\\n}\\n\\nreturn $res\\n}\\n\\n$val = Get-UserNameSIDfromAD -LoginName 'mydomain\\user1'\\n$val | Select-Object -Property ID, SqlSID, Message | Out-GridView\\n```","labels":["Incorrect (Code)"]}]
GPT_Answer:
The issue you're encountering is due to the way PowerShell handles objects and how they are displayed in the grid view. When you return a custom object from a function, PowerShell doesn't automatically display all its properties in the grid view. Instead, it only shows the properties that are defined in the object's default display format.

To resolve this issue, you can use the `Select-Object` cmdlet to specify which properties you want to display in the grid view. Here's an updated version of your code:

```powershell
function Get-UserNameSIDfromAD {
    param(
        [string] $LoginName
    )
    
    [string] $domain
    [string] $username
    
    $domain, $username = $LoginName.split('\')
    
    $w32usracc = Get-CimInstance -ClassName win32_useraccount -Filter "Name='$username' and Domain='$domain'" | Select-Object -Property SID
    
    $res = [pscustomobject] @{
        ID      = 1
        SqlSID  = $w32usracc.SID
        Message = 'OK'
    }
    
    return $res
}

$val = Get-UserNameSIDfromAD -LoginName 'mydomain\user1'
$val | Select-Object -Property ID, SqlSID, Message | Out-GridView
```

By using `Select-Object`, you're explicitly telling PowerShell which properties to display in the grid view. This should resolve the issue and display the correct information.

Alternatively, you can also use the `Format-Table` cmdlet to achieve the same result:

```powershell
$val | Format-Table -Property ID, SqlSID, Message | Out-GridView
```

This will format the output as a table with the specified properties and then pipe it to the grid view.
Title: Powershell function return pscustomobject out-gridview show incorrectly results

AnswerContent:
There is an issue related to this in the GitHub repository: microsoft/vscode #237740 issue

Turning off PL/SQL, PostgreSQL or any extension that depends on them worked for me

It's a bug in the vscode-database-client extension v8.1.1, see cweijan/vscode-database-client#1392.

Installing v8.1.0 fixes it.

By the way, this icon is mentioned in the description of the add-on. It seems that on January 14, 2025, a version 8.1.2 update was recently released.

Execute SQL Query

In the Database Explorer panel, click the Open Query button.
Body:
My VS Code from one day to another started appearing this icon as if it were a chain, next to the first line of files, and if skip line begins to appear in all, has anyone gone through this problem?
I'm thinking it's some extension, because I didn't touch anything and out of nowhere it appeared.
Conciseness_Not_Concise: [{"start":0,"end":2011,"text":"The icon you're referring to is likely the \"GitLens\" icon, which is a popular extension for Visual Studio Code (VS Code) that provides Git version control features. The icon appears as a chain link and indicates that the file has been modified or is being tracked by Git.\\n\\nTo resolve this issue, you can try the following steps:\\n\\n1. Check if you have the GitLens extension installed: Open the Extensions panel in VS Code by pressing `Ctrl + Shift + X` (Windows\/Linux) or `Cmd + Shift + X` (macOS). Search for \"GitLens\" in the search bar and see if it's listed. If it is, you can try disabling or uninstalling it to see if that resolves the issue.\\n2. Check your Git configuration: Open the Command Palette in VS Code by pressing `Ctrl + Shift + P` (Windows\/Linux) or `Cmd + Shift + P` (macOS). Type \"Git: Show Git Output\" and press Enter. This will open the Git output panel, where you can see if there are any errors or warnings related to Git.\\n3. Check your file system: Make sure that the file you're working on is not being tracked by Git. You can do this by running the command `git status` in the terminal or command prompt. If the file is being tracked, you may need to remove it from the Git index using the command `git rm --cached <file_name>`.\\n4. Reset VS Code settings: If none of the above steps work, you can try resetting your VS Code settings to their default values. To do this, open the Command Palette and type \"Reset Settings\" and press Enter. This will reset all your VS Code settings to their default values.\\n\\nIf none of these steps resolve the issue, you may want to try reinstalling VS Code or seeking further assistance from the VS Code community or support team.\\n\\n**Answer:** The icon you're referring to is likely the GitLens icon, which indicates that the file has been modified or is being tracked by Git. You can try disabling or uninstalling the GitLens extension, checking your Git configuration, checking your file system, or resetting your VS Code settings to resolve the issue.","labels":["Not Concise (Irrelevant)"]}]

GPT_Answer:
The icon you're referring to is likely the "GitLens" icon, which is a popular extension for Visual Studio Code (VS Code) that provides Git version control features. The icon appears as a chain link and indicates that the file has been modified or is being tracked by Git.

To resolve this issue, you can try the following steps:

1. Check if you have the GitLens extension installed: Open the Extensions panel in VS Code by pressing `Ctrl + Shift + X` (Windows/Linux) or `Cmd + Shift + X` (macOS). Search for "GitLens" in the search bar and see if it's listed. If it is, you can try disabling or uninstalling it to see if that resolves the issue.
2. Check your Git configuration: Open the Command Palette in VS Code by pressing `Ctrl + Shift + P` (Windows/Linux) or `Cmd + Shift + P` (macOS). Type "Git: Show Git Output" and press Enter. This will open the Git output panel, where you can see if there are any errors or warnings related to Git.
3. Check your file system: Make sure that the file you're working on is not being tracked by Git. You can do this by running the command `git status` in the terminal or command prompt. If the file is being tracked, you may need to remove it from the Git index using the command `git rm --cached <file_name>`.
4. Reset VS Code settings: If none of the above steps work, you can try resetting your VS Code settings to their default values. To do this, open the Command Palette and type "Reset Settings" and press Enter. This will reset all your VS Code settings to their default values.

If none of these steps resolve the issue, you may want to try reinstalling VS Code or seeking further assistance from the VS Code community or support team.

**Answer:** The icon you're referring to is likely the GitLens icon, which indicates that the file has been modified or is being tracked by Git. You can try disabling or uninstalling the GitLens extension, checking your Git configuration, checking your file system, or resetting your VS Code settings to resolve the issue.
Title: Icon "chain" vscode

AnswerContent:
follow @Topaco advice "All modes (with the exception of the insecure ECB mode) require an IV for decryption. For GCM, the recommended IV length is 12 bytes (although other IV lengths are technically possible). It is common to concatenate IV (because it is not secret) and ciphertext during encryption" my current workable code is:

private SecretKey decryptDataKey(byte[] encryptedDataKey, byte[] iv) throws NoSuchAlgorithmException, InvalidKeyException,
        NoSuchPaddingException, IllegalBlockSizeException, BadPaddingException, UnrecoverableKeyException, java.security.KeyStoreException, InvalidAlgorithmParameterException, NoSuchProviderException {
    Key masterKey = getOrCreateKey();
    Cipher cipher = Cipher.getInstance(transformation);
    GCMParameterSpec gcmParameterSpec = new GCMParameterSpec(gcmTagLength, iv);
    cipher.init(Cipher.DECRYPT_MODE, masterKey, gcmParameterSpec);
    byte[] decryptedDataKey = cipher.doFinal(encryptedDataKey);
    return new SecretKeySpec(decryptedDataKey, KeyProperties.KEY_ALGORITHM_AES);
}
Title: How to initialize cipher.init(Cipher.DECRYPT_MODE, masterKey) - IV required when decrypting. Use IvParameterSpec or AlgorithmParameters to provide it

AnswerContent:
You have two different declarations of the test_nested structure.

The first is the one you declare in the global scope, which is really named ::test_nested. Then there's the one you declare inside the test class, which has the name ::test::test_nested (or just test::test_nested for short).

In the main function you use ::test_nested, not test::test_nested, which leads top your error.

Use the correct structure and the error should disappear.
GPT_Answer:
The error message indicates that the compiler is unable to initialize a variable of type 'test_nested *' with an rvalue of type 'test_nested *'. This is because the 'test_nested' class is a nested class within the 'test' class, and its scope is limited to the 'test' class.

To fix this issue, you need to use the scope resolution operator '::' to access the 'test_nested' class from outside the 'test' class. Here's the corrected code:

```cpp
test::test_nested* temp = A.connect(6);
```

By using the scope resolution operator '::', you are telling the compiler to look for the 'test_nested' class within the 'test' class. This should resolve the error and allow you to compile the code successfully.

Additionally, you should also consider using smart pointers instead of raw pointers to manage memory in your code. This will help prevent memory leaks and make your code more robust.
Title: Cannot initialize a variable of type 'test_nested *' with an rvalue of type 'test_nested *' (aka 'test::test_nested *') using nested class, pointers

GPT_Answer:
The error message indicates that the target machine is actively refusing the connection. This could be due to a variety of reasons, including:

1. **Firewall rules**: The firewall on your local machine may be blocking the connection to the Azure Storage Emulator.
2. **Azure Storage Emulator not running**: The Azure Storage Emulator may not be running or may not be configured correctly.
3. **Incorrect configuration**: The `local.settings.json` file may not be configured correctly, or there may be a mismatch between the configuration and the Azure Storage Emulator settings.

To resolve this issue, you can try the following steps:

1. **Check the Azure Storage Emulator**: Ensure that the Azure Storage Emulator is running and configured correctly. You can check the status of the emulator by running the command `AzureStorageEmulator.exe status` in the Command Prompt.
2. **Check the firewall rules**: Check the firewall rules on your local machine to ensure that they are not blocking the connection to the Azure Storage Emulator. You can add an exception to the firewall rules to allow incoming connections to the emulator.
3. **Verify the local.settings.json file**: Verify that the `local.settings.json` file is configured correctly. Ensure that the `AzureWebJobsStorage` setting is set to the correct value, and that the `AzureWebJobsSecretStorageType` setting is set to "files".
4. **Try running the Azure Functions with the --verbose flag**: Run the Azure Functions with the `--verbose` flag to get more detailed output. This may help you identify the root cause of the issue.
5. **Check for conflicts with other Azure services**: If you have other Azure services running on your local machine, such as Azure Cosmos DB or Azure Service Bus, they may be conflicting with the Azure Storage Emulator. Try stopping these services and see if the issue resolves.

If none of these steps resolve the issue, you may want to try resetting the Azure Storage Emulator or reinstalling the Azure Functions runtime.

AnswerContent:
It turned out the sample I was using did not have the correct values for schemas and extra_search_path inside config.toml. They should look like:

schemas = ["public", "graphql_public"]
extra_search_path = ["public", "extensions"]

**Step 1: Identify the issue**

The error message indicates that there is a problem with the schema. The error code "PGRST106" suggests that the schema is not valid.

**Step 2: Check the schema**

Check the schema of your Supabase database to ensure that it matches the expected schema. You can do this by running the following command in your terminal:

```
supabase schema
```

This will display the current schema of your database.

**Step 3: Update the schema**

If the schema is not correct, you need to update it to match the expected schema. You can do this by running the following command:

```
supabase schema update
```

This will update the schema to match the expected schema.

**Step 4: Verify the schema**

After updating the schema, verify that it is correct by running the following command:

```
supabase schema
```

This will display the updated schema.

**Step 5: Test the application**

Once the schema is updated and verified, test the application again to see if the error is resolved.

**Answer**: The issue is likely due to an incorrect schema in your local Supabase database. To resolve the issue, you need to update the schema to match the expected schema. You can do this by running the `supabase schema update` command and then verifying the schema using the `supabase schema` command. After updating and verifying the schema, test the application again to see if the error is resolved.

AnswerContent:
You are over-complicating things. Yu do not need the second function. Do this instead:

from ipywidgets import interact
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

df = pd.DataFrame(index=[1, 2, 3], 
                  data={'col1': [2, 3, 5], "col2": [2, 5, 2], "col3": [2, 4, 3]})

def df_plot(num):
    plt.figure() 
    df.iloc[:, num].plot(kind='line', title=f"Column {num + 1}")
    plt.show()

interact(df_plot, num=(0, len(df.columns) - 1))

which gives
Body:
from ipywidgets import interact
import ipywidgets as widgets
import pandas as pd

I have a dataframe as below:
df = pd.DataFrame(index = [1,2,3], 
                   data = {'col1':[2,3,5],"col2":[2,5,2], "col3":[2,4,3]})

In addition I have a function df_plot that draws a line plot. Through a number argument I select which column to be drawn.
def df_plot(df, num):
    df.iloc[:,num].plot()

Trying to create another function f_interact that displays dropdown where I can choose which column to be plotted.
df_plot is used in f_interact
def f_interact():
    widgets.interact(df_plot, num=[0,1,2])

I receive the following error

I most probably don't construct the set-up (functions and arguments) correctly.
I went over ipywidgets documentation but cannot find a proper example.
Can someone advise.
Code_Error_Type: [{"start":681,"end":1462,"text":"```python\\nimport pandas as pd\\nimport ipywidgets as widgets\\nfrom ipywidgets import interact\\nimport matplotlib.pyplot as plt\\n\\n# Create a sample DataFrame\\ndf = pd.DataFrame(index=[1, 2, 3],\\ndata={'col1': [2, 3, 5], \"col2\": [2, 5, 2], \"col3\": [2, 4, 3]})\\n\\n# Define a function to plot a column\\ndef df_plot(num):\\ndf.iloc[:, num].plot()\\nplt.show()\\n\\n# Define a function to create the interact widget\\ndef f_interact():\\n# Create a dropdown widget for the column selection\\ncolumn_widget = widgets.Dropdown(options=['col1', 'col2', 'col3'], value='col1', description='Column:')\\n\\n# Create the interact widget\\ninteract(df_plot, num=[0, 1, 2])\\n\\n# Display the column widget\\ndisplay(column_widget)\\n\\n# Call the f_interact function\\nf_interact()\\n```","labels":["Wrong Logic"]}]
Consistency_Inconsistent: [{"start":681,"end":1462,"text":"```python\\nimport pandas as pd\\nimport ipywidgets as widgets\\nfrom ipywidgets import interact\\nimport matplotlib.pyplot as plt\\n\\n# Create a sample DataFrame\\ndf = pd.DataFrame(index=[1, 2, 3],\\ndata={'col1': [2, 3, 5], \"col2\": [2, 5, 2], \"col3\": [2, 4, 3]})\\n\\n# Define a function to plot a column\\ndef df_plot(num):\\ndf.iloc[:, num].plot()\\nplt.show()\\n\\n# Define a function to create the interact widget\\ndef f_interact():\\n# Create a dropdown widget for the column selection\\ncolumn_widget = widgets.Dropdown(options=['col1', 'col2', 'col3'], value='col1', description='Column:')\\n\\n# Create the interact widget\\ninteract(df_plot, num=[0, 1, 2])\\n\\n# Display the column widget\\ndisplay(column_widget)\\n\\n# Call the f_interact function\\nf_interact()\\n```","labels":["Inconsistent (Code)"]}]
Correctness_Incorrect: [{"start":681,"end":1462,"text":"```python\\nimport pandas as pd\\nimport ipywidgets as widgets\\nfrom ipywidgets import interact\\nimport matplotlib.pyplot as plt\\n\\n# Create a sample DataFrame\\ndf = pd.DataFrame(index=[1, 2, 3],\\ndata={'col1': [2, 3, 5], \"col2\": [2, 5, 2], \"col3\": [2, 4, 3]})\\n\\n# Define a function to plot a column\\ndef df_plot(num):\\ndf.iloc[:, num].plot()\\nplt.show()\\n\\n# Define a function to create the interact widget\\ndef f_interact():\\n# Create a dropdown widget for the column selection\\ncolumn_widget = widgets.Dropdown(options=['col1', 'col2', 'col3'], value='col1', description='Column:')\\n\\n# Create the interact widget\\ninteract(df_plot, num=[0, 1, 2])\\n\\n# Display the column widget\\ndisplay(column_widget)\\n\\n# Call the f_interact function\\nf_interact()\\n```","labels":["Incorrect (Code)"]}]
GPT_Answer:
The error you're encountering is due to the incorrect usage of the `interact` function from `ipywidgets`. The `interact` function expects a function as its first argument, and then keyword arguments that specify the widgets to be used for each parameter of the function. In your case, you're passing `df_plot` as the first argument, but you're not specifying the widget for the `df` parameter.

To fix this, you need to specify a widget for the `df` parameter. Since `df` is a DataFrame, you can't directly use it as a widget. Instead, you can create a dropdown widget that allows the user to select which column to plot.

Here's an updated version of your code that should work:

```python
import pandas as pd
import ipywidgets as widgets
from ipywidgets import interact
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Create a sample DataFrame
df = pd.DataFrame(index=[1, 2, 3], 
                   data={'col1': [2, 3, 5], "col2": [2, 5, 2], "col3": [2, 4, 3]})

# Define a function to plot a column
def df_plot(num):
    df.iloc[:, num].plot()
    plt.show()

# Define a function to create the interact widget
def f_interact():
    # Create a dropdown widget for the column selection
    column_widget = widgets.Dropdown(options=['col1', 'col2', 'col3'], value='col1', description='Column:')

    # Create the interact widget
    interact(df_plot, num=[0, 1, 2])

    # Display the column widget
    display(column_widget)

# Call the f_interact function
f_interact()
```

In this updated code, we define a `df_plot` function that takes a single argument `num`, which specifies the column to plot. We then define a `f_interact` function that creates a dropdown widget for selecting the column and calls the `interact` function with the `df_plot` function and the column widget.

Note that we've also added a `display` statement to display the column widget. This is necessary because the `interact` function only displays the output of the function, not the widgets themselves.

I hope this helps. Let me know if you have any further questions.
Title: How to properly use function with dataframe argument in another ipywidget interact function

AnswerContent:
The error is coming from the below line.

 [ERROR] NG2: Type '{ apiVersion: number; apiVersionMinor: number; allowedPaymentMethods: { type: string; parameters: { allowedAuthMethods: string[]; allowedCardNetworks: string[]; }; tokenizationSpecification: { ...; }; }[]; merchantInfo: { ...; }; transactionInfo: { ...; }; }' is not assignable to type 'PaymentDataRequest'.
  Types of property 'allowedPaymentMethods' are incompatible.
    Type '{ type: string; parameters: { allowedAuthMethods: string[]; allowedCardNetworks: string[]; }; tokenizationSpecification: { type: string; parameters: { gateway: string; gatewayMerchantId: string; }; }; }[]' is not assignable to type 'PaymentMethodSpecification[]'.
      Type '{ type: string; parameters: { allowedAuthMethods: string[]; allowedCardNetworks: string[]; }; tokenizationSpecification: { type: string; parameters: { gateway: string; gatewayMerchantId: string; }; }; }' is not assignable to type 'PaymentMethodSpecification'.
        Types of property 'type' are incompatible.
          Type 'string' is not assignable to type 'PaymentMethodType'. [plugin angular-compiler]

When I lookup the type of PaymentMethodType in DefinetlyTyped for google pay.

index.d.ts - github

type PaymentMethodType = "CARD" | "PAYPAL";

So you are passing value as string, but it is not matching with this type. To solve this problem, I first installed the typings for google pay from the below package:

@types/googlepay

npm install --save @types/googlepay

Then we can strict type the property which you pass as input to the google pay component.

  paymentRequest: google.payments.api.PaymentDataRequest = {
    apiVersion: 2,
    apiVersionMinor: 0,
    allowedPaymentMethods: [
      ...

Now your code should compile. The problem was the string you set 'CARD' was not recognized for the union type "CARD" | "PAYPAL", When we strict type the object, typescript recognizes the configuration and the error goes away.

Github Repo
Conciseness_Not_Concise: [{"start":1596,"end":1989,"text":"Additionally, you can also update your `tsconfig.json` file to include the following settings:\\n\\n```json\\n{\\n\"compilerOptions\": {\\n\/\/ ... other settings ...\\n\"strict\": true,\\n\"strictPropertyInitialization\": true,\\n\"strictNullChecks\": true,\\n\"strictFunctionTypes\": true,\\n\"strictBindCallApply\": true,\\n\"strictNullChecks\": true,\\n\"strictPropertyInitialization\": true\\n}\\n}","labels":["Not Concise (Irrelevant)"]}]
Title: Google-pay-button paymentRequest typeErrors when building

AnswerContent:
& is the intersection type. An intersection of two types A and B like type T = A & B means that T should have all props from A and B.

If you check this playground:

type X = null & {};

X is never.

Because type X now wants to be a type which is assignable of both null and empty object type, but Empty Object Type is used to represent any value except null and undefined. Every other type string,number and of course object is assignable to {}, as primitive types also have their own properties.

And that is how NonNullable also works, by creating an intersection of the two.
Body:
Today, when I was looking at the ts definition file, I found that '&{}' is used here, but I can't understand why & {} can exclude null and undefined in TypeScript.In Javascript '&' mean is bitwise and

And I didn't look up the relevant information. Can you help me explain or  tell me where I can look it up
GPT_Answer:
The `& {}` syntax in TypeScript is not related to the bitwise AND operator (`&`) in JavaScript. Instead, it's a type intersection operator.

In TypeScript, the `&` symbol is used to create an intersection type, which combines two or more types into a new type that has all the properties of each individual type. When you use `& {}`, you're creating an intersection type between the type on the left side of the `&` and an empty object type (`{}`).

The empty object type (`{}`) is a type that has no properties. When you intersect this type with another type, the resulting type will have all the properties of the original type, but with the additional constraint that it cannot be `null` or `undefined`.

This is because the empty object type (`{}`) does not have a `null` or `undefined` value, so when you intersect it with another type, the resulting type will also exclude `null` and `undefined` values.

In other words, `& {}` is a way to create a type that is non-nullable and non-undefined, which is useful in TypeScript for ensuring that certain values are not null or undefined.

You can find more information about type intersections and the `&` operator in the TypeScript documentation:

*   [Type Intersections](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/2/objects.html#intersection-types)
*   [Type Operators](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/2/types.html#type-operators)

I hope this helps clarify things for you. Let me know if you have any further questions.
Title: why & {} can exclude null and undefined in TypeScript

GPT_Answer:
The issue you're experiencing with the com.github.barteksc:android-pdf-viewer package not resolving through JitPack, Maven Central, Gradle, or any other repository is likely due to the fact that the package has been removed from these repositories. 

The package was previously available on JitPack, but it has since been removed. The package is no longer available on Maven Central or Gradle either. 

To resolve this issue, you can try the following:

1. Check if the package is available on other repositories: You can try searching for the package on other repositories such as Bintray or GitHub Packages. If the package is available on one of these repositories, you can add the repository to your build.gradle file and try to resolve the package again.

2. Use a different version of the package: If the package is no longer available on any repository, you can try using a different version of the package. You can check the package's documentation or GitHub page to see if there are any other versions available.

3. Contact the package maintainer: If you are unable to find the package on any repository or use a different version, you can try contacting the package maintainer to see if they have any information about the package's availability.

4. Use a different package: If none of the above options work, you may need to consider using a different package that provides similar functionality.

Here is an example of how you can add a repository to your build.gradle file:

```groovy
repositories {
    maven { url 'https://jitpack.io' }
    maven { url 'https://maven.google.com' }
    maven { url 'https://dl.bintray.com/username/repository' }
}
```

Replace "username" and "repository" with the actual username and repository name of the package you are trying to use.

I hope this helps you resolve the issue with the com.github.barteksc:android-pdf-viewer package.

AnswerContent:
The issue is not originating from the code block you provided, rather it is originating from line 15:

quarter_scores = ', '.join([f"Q{q['Number']}: {q.get('AwayScore', 'N/A')}-{q.get('HomeScore', 'N/A')}" for q in quarters])

Error message states quarters is None.

Indeed, in the data you fetched, quarters is null, (json.loads function turns null into None)

Solution:

before iterating, make sure quarters is not None.
Body:
its an aws lambda function
   try:
       with  urllib.request.urlopen(api_url) as response:
           data=json.loads(response.read().decode())
           print(json.dumps(data, indent = 4 ))
   except Exception as e :
       print(f"error reading data : {e} ")
       return {"statuscode":"500","body":"Error fetching data"}

   games_messages = [game_format(game) for game in data]

the error that I get :
  "errorMessage": "'NoneType' object is not iterable",
  "errorType": "TypeError",
  "requestId": "11a9a46e-3abe-4f6e-8c38-278c0697238a",
  "stackTrace": [
    "  File \"/var/task/lambda_function.py\", line 69, in lambda_handler\n    games_messages = [game_format(game) for game in data]\n",
    "  File \"/var/task/lambda_function.py\", line 15, in game_format\n    quarter_scores = ', '.join([f\"Q{q['Number']}: {q.get('AwayScore', 'N/A')}-{q.get('HomeScore', 'N/A')}\" for q in quarters])\n"
  ]
}

the data that I fetched:
Consistency_Inconsistent: [{"start":498,"end":870,"text":"```python\\ndef game_format(game):\\n# ... (rest of your code remains the same)\\n\\nif 'Quarters' in game and game['Quarters'] is not None:\\nquarter_scores = ', '.join([f\"Q{q['Number']}: {q.get('AwayScore', 'N\/A')}-{q.get('HomeScore', 'N\/A')}\" for q in game['Quarters']])\\nelse:\\nquarter_scores = 'N\/A'\\n\\n# ... (rest of your code remains the same)\\n```","labels":["Inconsistent (Code)"]}]
GPT_Answer:
The error message indicates that the 'NoneType' object is not iterable, which means that the variable 'quarters' in your game_format function is None. This could be due to the fact that the 'Game' object does not have a 'Quarters' key or the 'Quarters' key has a value of None.

To fix this issue, you need to add a check to ensure that the 'Quarters' key exists in the 'Game' object and its value is not None before trying to iterate over it. Here's how you can modify your game_format function:

```python
def game_format(game):
    # ... (rest of your code remains the same)

    if 'Quarters' in game and game['Quarters'] is not None:
        quarter_scores = ', '.join([f"Q{q['Number']}: {q.get('AwayScore', 'N/A')}-{q.get('HomeScore', 'N/A')}" for q in game['Quarters']])
    else:
        quarter_scores = 'N/A'

    # ... (rest of your code remains the same)
```

This modification will prevent the TypeError from occurring when the 'Quarters' key is missing or has a value of None. Instead, it will display 'N/A' for the quarter scores in such cases.
Title: "errorMessage": "'NoneType' object is not iterable"

AnswerContent:
Looks like Electron finds and executes your preload script, but throws an error while executing the script:

Error: contextBridge API can only be used when contextIsolation is enabled

Seems pretty straightforward to fix: just enable context isolation in your BrowserWindow options.

Or, alternatively, don't use the contextBridge API in your preload script if context isolation is disabled:

// preload.ts
// ...

if (process.contextIsolated) {
  contextBridge.exposeInMainWorld("myAPI", { foo: "bar" });
} else {
  window.myAPI = { foo: "bar" };
}

AnswerContent: You can do this in Settings > Keymap. On the top left, you can search for "maven", then in the Keymap section, under Maven, you can "Choose a phase/goal to assign a shortcut".
Body:
I am developing java maven projects using IntelliJ.
In order to compile the project with its dependencies, I use a lot mvn clean install
Every time, I end up clicking hte UI on this icon, then clicking on reload (please see screenshot)
I tried biding this action to a button on the keyboard or in the mouse.
However, I could not find which action is it.
The closest I could find was binding "Run Configuration", however, this does not take into account everything (all the steps from the screenshot)

Question:
How to bind mvn clean install to a button?
Consistency_Inconsistent: [{"start":641,"end":1442,"text":"Alternatively, you can also use the \"Maven Projects\" tool window to bind the \"mvn clean install\" action to a button. To do this:\\n\\n1. Open the \"Maven Projects\" tool window by clicking on the \"Maven Projects\" button in the top-right corner of the IntelliJ window.\\n2. In the \"Maven Projects\" tool window, right-click on the project root and select \"Add Configuration\".\\n3. In the \"Add Configuration\" dialog, select \"Maven\" as the configuration type and \"clean install\" as the goal.\\n4. Click \"OK\" to save the configuration.\\n5. To bind the configuration to a button, click on the \"...\" button next to the \"Configuration\" field and select \"Bind to Button\".\\n6. Select a button from the list of available buttons or create a new button by clicking on the \"New Button\" button.\\n7. Click \"OK\" to save the binding.\\n","labels":["Inconsistent (Number of Solutions)"]}]
GPT_Answer:
To bind the "mvn clean install" action to a button in IntelliJ, you can follow these steps:

1. Open the "Settings" dialog by pressing `Ctrl + Shift + Alt + S` (Windows/Linux) or `Cmd + Shift + Alt + S` (Mac).
2. In the "Settings" dialog, navigate to "Keymap" under the "Appearance & Behavior" section.
3. In the "Keymap" section, click on the "Add Keyboard Shortcut" button.
4. In the "Add Keyboard Shortcut" dialog, select "Maven" as the category and "Execute Maven Goal" as the action.
5. Click on the "..." button next to the "Goal" field and select "clean install" from the list of available goals.
6. Click "OK" to save the shortcut.

Alternatively, you can also use the "Maven Projects" tool window to bind the "mvn clean install" action to a button. To do this:

1. Open the "Maven Projects" tool window by clicking on the "Maven Projects" button in the top-right corner of the IntelliJ window.
2. In the "Maven Projects" tool window, right-click on the project root and select "Add Configuration".
3. In the "Add Configuration" dialog, select "Maven" as the configuration type and "clean install" as the goal.
4. Click "OK" to save the configuration.
5. To bind the configuration to a button, click on the "..." button next to the "Configuration" field and select "Bind to Button".
6. Select a button from the list of available buttons or create a new button by clicking on the "New Button" button.
7. Click "OK" to save the binding.

By following these steps, you should be able to bind the "mvn clean install" action to a button in IntelliJ.
Title: IntelliJ - Bring mvn clean install to a button

This setting allows you to exclude specific files or folders from the search results.\\n","labels":["Inconsistent (Factual)"]},{"start":524,"end":597,"text":"```\\n\"files.exclude\": {\\n\"**\/obj\/*\": true,\\n\"**\/debug\/*\": true\\n}\\n```","labels":["Inconsistent (Code)"]},{"start":702,"end":1201,"text":". This setting is specific to the search functionality and does not affect other features like file navigation.\\n\\nTo exclude files and folders from the search results for the entire VS Code instance, you can add the following line to the settings.json file:\\n```\\n\"search.exclude\": {\\n\"**\/obj\/*\": true,\\n\"**\/debug\/*\": true\\n}\\n```","labels":["Inconsistent (Number of Solutions)"]}]
Correctness_Incorrect: [{"start":0,"end":247,"text":"To avoid unnecessary folders and files like obj\/debug and get the project-related files only while searching in VS Code, you can use the \"files.exclude\" setting. This setting allows you to exclude specific files or folders from the search results.\\n","labels":["Incorrect (Factual)"]}]
GPT_Answer:
To avoid unnecessary folders and files like obj/debug and get the project-related files only while searching in VS Code, you can use the "files.exclude" setting. This setting allows you to exclude specific files or folders from the search results.

Here's how you can do it:

1. Open the Command Palette in VS Code by pressing Ctrl + Shift + P (Windows/Linux) or Cmd + Shift + P (Mac).
2. Type "Open Settings (JSON)" and select the option to open the settings.json file.
3. Add the following line to the settings.json file:
```
"files.exclude": {
    "**/obj/*": true,
    "**/debug/*": true
}
```
This will exclude all files and folders inside the obj and debug directories from the search results.

4. Save the changes to the settings.json file.

Alternatively, you can also use the "search.exclude" setting to exclude specific files or folders from the search results. This setting is specific to the search functionality and does not affect other features like file navigation.

To exclude files and folders from the search results for the entire VS Code instance, you can add the following line to the settings.json file:
```
"search.exclude": {
    "**/obj/*": true,
    "**/debug/*": true
}
```
This will exclude all files and folders inside the obj and debug directories from the search results for all projects in VS Code.

Note that the "**" wildcard is used to match any directory or subdirectory, so the exclusion will apply to all obj and debug directories regardless of their location in the project.

By using these settings, you can avoid unnecessary folders and files like obj/debug and get the project-related files only while searching in VS Code.
Title: While searching in VS code, how to avoid unnecessary folders and files like obj/debug and get the project related files only

AnswerContent:
The whereIn clause checks if a single-value field has one of multiple possible values.

Your groupId is an array field, so you need to use arrayContains:

.where('groupId', arrayContains: 'oVF05dlEdzS3vdj3TvSG')

Also see the Firebase documentation on querying by array membership.
Body:
I have the code
QuerySnapshot snapshot = await FirebaseFirestore.instance
        .collection('Posts')
        .where('groupId', whereIn: [
          'oVF05dlEdzS3vdj3TvSG'
        ]) // Using whereIn for multiple groups
        .orderBy('createdAtTimestamp', descending: true)
        .startAfterDocument(_lastDocument!)
        .limit(_numberOfPosts)
        .get();

This query worked fine before i added this .where filter looking at groupIds.
I then added a groupId filter and used a group as an example. I currently have one Post document that has the groupId as you can see with the exact same id. Why is it returning 0 posts? Is there something I'm missing?

There will only be 5 groups max so its ok.

Here's the corrected code:\\n\\n```dart\\nQuerySnapshot snapshot = await FirebaseFirestore.instance\\n.collection('Posts')\\n.where('groupId', isEqualTo: 'oVF05dlEdzS3vdj3TvSG')\\n.orderBy('createdAtTimestamp', descending: true)\\n.startAfterDocument(_lastDocument!)\\n.limit(_numberOfPosts)\\n.get","labels":["Not Concise (Irrelevant)"]}]
Consistency_Inconsistent: [{"start":668,"end":768,"text":"If you need to filter by multiple groups, you can use the `whereIn` method with a list of group IDs:","labels":["Inconsistent (Factual)"]},{"start":770,"end":1127,"text":"```dart\\nList<String> groupIds = ['oVF05dlEdzS3vdj3TvSG', 'anotherGroupId', 'yetAnotherGroupId'];\\n\\nQuerySnapshot snapshot = await FirebaseFirestore.instance\\n.collection('Posts')\\n.where('groupId', whereIn: groupIds)\\n.orderBy('createdAtTimestamp', descending: true)\\n.startAfterDocument(_lastDocument!)\\n.limit(_numberOfPosts)\\n.get();\\n```","labels":["Inconsistent (Code)"]},{"start":668,"end":1127,"text":"If you need to filter by multiple groups, you can use the `whereIn` method with a list of group IDs:\\n\\n```dart\\nList<String> groupIds = ['oVF05dlEdzS3vdj3TvSG', 'anotherGroupId', 'yetAnotherGroupId'];\\n\\nQuerySnapshot snapshot = await FirebaseFirestore.instance\\n.collection('Posts')\\n.where('groupId', whereIn: groupIds)\\n.orderBy('createdAtTimestamp', descending: true)\\n.startAfterDocument(_lastDocument!)\\n.limit(_numberOfPosts)\\n.get();\\n```","labels":["Inconsistent (Number of Solutions)"]}]
Correctness_Incorrect: [{"start":668,"end":767,"text":"If you need to filter by multiple groups, you can use the `whereIn` method with a list of group IDs","labels":["Incorrect (Factual)"]},{"start":770,"end":1127,"text":"```dart\\nList<String> groupIds = ['oVF05dlEdzS3vdj3TvSG', 'anotherGroupId', 'yetAnotherGroupId'];\\n\\nQuerySnapshot snapshot = await FirebaseFirestore.instance\\n.collection('Posts')\\n.where('groupId', whereIn: groupIds)\\n.orderBy('createdAtTimestamp', descending: true)\\n.startAfterDocument(_lastDocument!)\\n.limit(_numberOfPosts)\\n.get();\\n```","labels":["Incorrect (Code)","Incorrect (Terminology)"]},{"start":307,"end":590,"text":"```dart\\nQuerySnapshot snapshot = await FirebaseFirestore.instance\\n.collection('Posts')\\n.where('groupId', isEqualTo: 'oVF05dlEdzS3vdj3TvSG')\\n.orderBy('createdAtTimestamp', descending: true)\\n.startAfterDocument(_lastDocument!)\\n.limit(_numberOfPosts)\\n.get();\\n```","labels":["Incorrect (Terminology)"]}]
GPT_Answer:
The issue lies in the fact that you are using `whereIn` with a single value. The `whereIn` method is used to filter documents based on a list of values, but in your case, you are only providing one value.

To fix this, you can simply use the `where` method instead of `whereIn`. Here's the corrected code:

```dart
QuerySnapshot snapshot = await FirebaseFirestore.instance
    .collection('Posts')
    .where('groupId', isEqualTo: 'oVF05dlEdzS3vdj3TvSG')
    .orderBy('createdAtTimestamp', descending: true)
    .startAfterDocument(_lastDocument!)
    .limit(_numberOfPosts)
    .get();
```

This will correctly filter the documents based on the specified `groupId`.

If you need to filter by multiple groups, you can use the `whereIn` method with a list of group IDs:

```dart
List<String> groupIds = ['oVF05dlEdzS3vdj3TvSG', 'anotherGroupId', 'yetAnotherGroupId'];

QuerySnapshot snapshot = await FirebaseFirestore.instance
    .collection('Posts')
    .where('groupId', whereIn: groupIds)
    .orderBy('createdAtTimestamp', descending: true)
    .startAfterDocument(_lastDocument!)
    .limit(_numberOfPosts)
    .get();
```

Make sure to replace the `groupIds` list with the actual group IDs you want to filter by.
Title: Flutter Firebase Query: whereIn filter returning 0 posts

AnswerContent:
since you render your quarto with LaTeX to PDF, we can add a cutom header to overwrite the enumerate (1.,2.,3.,...) and itemize (bulletpoints) like this:

---
title: "test list"
format: 
  pdf:
    include-in-header:
      text: |
        \usepackage{enumitem}
        \setlist[itemize]{topsep=0pt,itemsep=0pt,partopsep=0pt,parsep=0pt}
        \setlist[enumerate]{topsep=0pt,itemsep=0pt,partopsep=0pt,parsep=0pt}
---

1. First
2. Second
    + sub 1
3. Third
Body:
How do I remove the extra space added before and after sub-bullets in a quarto PDF document? [Apparently I need more text before stackoverflow will allow me to post this question. But my question is pretty straight-forward. I just want to get rid of the ugly and confusing white space that's added into the middle of my list.]
---
title: "test list"
format: pdf
---

1. First
2. Second
    + sub 1
3. Third
Conciseness_Not_Concise: [{"start":151,"end":305,"text":"```markdown\\n---\\ntitle: \"test list\"\\nformat: pdf\\n---\\n\\n1. First\\n2. Second\\n+ sub 1\\n3. Third\\n\\n:::{.compact}\\n1. First\\n2. Second\\n+ sub 1\\n3. Third\\n:::\\n```","labels":["Not Concise (Excess)"]}]
Consistency_Inconsistent: [{"start":151,"end":305,"text":"```markdown\\n---\\ntitle: \"test list\"\\nformat: pdf\\n---\\n\\n1. First\\n2. Second\\n+ sub 1\\n3. Third\\n\\n:::{.compact}\\n1. First\\n2. Second\\n+ sub 1\\n3. Third\\n:::\\n```","labels":["Inconsistent (Factual)","Inconsistent (Code)","Inconsistent (Terminology)","Inconsistent (Number of Solutions)"]}]
GPT_Answer:
To remove extra space around sub-bullets in a Quarto list, you can use the `compact` option in your YAML header. Here's how you can modify your code:

```markdown
---
title: "test list"
format: pdf
---

1. First
2. Second
    + sub 1
3. Third

:::{.compact}
1. First
2. Second
    + sub 1
3. Third
:::
```

In this example, the `compact` option is applied to the entire list. If you want to apply it only to the sub-bullets, you can wrap only the sub-bullets in the `compact` block:

```markdown
---
title: "test list"
format: pdf
---

1. First
2. Second
    ::: {.compact}
    + sub 1
    :::
3. Third
```

This will remove the extra space around the sub-bullets.
Title: How to remove extra space around sub-bullets in a Quarto list?

AnswerContent:
Vite dev and build have different toolchains (esbuild and Rollup), it's common for them to work differently. CommonJS modules are supposed to be imported as default in ES modules, so regardless of the configuration the correct way to use it is:

import eventsource from '...'
const {EventSourcePolyfill} = eventsource

optimizeDeps.include and build.commonjsOptions.include options may work for NPM packages but may not work for local modules.

This can be fixed by using local dependency and npm i:

  "dependencies": {
    "eventsource": "file:./src/utils/eventsource"
  }

This also requires to create dummy package.json file in src/utils/eventsource in order for it to be processed as a package, then it can be imported as eventsource.

Similarly, resolve.alias can be used in Vite configuration for the same purpose, this doesn't require extra package.json:

import { fileURLToPath, URL } from "url";
...
resolve: {
  alias: {
    "eventsource": fileURLToPath(new URL("./src", import.meta.url)) + '/utils/eventsource/index.js',
  }
},

Alternatively, Vite CommonJS plugin could be used (not to be confused with Rollup plugin that uses build.commonjsOptions.include):

import { defineConfig } from 'vite';
import commonjs from 'vite-plugin-commonjs'

export default defineConfig({
  plugins: [
    commonjs({
      filter(id) {
        return id.match(/[\/]src[\/]utils[\/]eventsource[\/]index.js/)
      }
      ...

Alternatively, the module could be rewritten as ESM instead of CJS/UMD with only few changes.

The following UMD wrapper:

(function (global) {
  "use strict";

  ...

  (function (factory) {
    if (typeof module === "object" && typeof module.exports === "object") {
      var v = factory(exports);
      if (v !== undefined) module.exports = v;
    }
    else if (typeof define === "function" && define.amd) {
      define(["exports"], factory);
    }
    else {
      factory(global);
    }
  })(function (exports) {
    exports.EventSourcePolyfill = EventSourcePolyfill;
    exports.NativeEventSource = NativeEventSource;
    exports.EventSource = R;
  });
}(typeof globalThis === 'undefined' ? (typeof window !== 'undefined' ? window : typeof self !== 'undefined' ? self : this) : globalThis));

Is replaced with :

export default (function (global) {
  "use strict";

  ...

  return {
    EventSourcePolyfill;
    NativeEventSource;
    EventSource: R;
  };
})(globalThis);
Title: why my vite config(optimizedeps.include) is not working?

AnswerContent:
I had the same problem after upgrading my system.

In my case, the solution was to remove configurations and data that Jupyter had stored at a couple of places throughout the system.

First, check which paths Jupyter is potentially using:

$> venv/bin/jupyter --paths
config:
    ./venv/etc/jupyter
    /home/<USER>/.jupyter
    /usr/local/etc/jupyter
    /etc/jupyter
data:
    ./venv/share/jupyter
    /home/<USER>/.local/share/jupyter
    /usr/local/share/jupyter
    /usr/share/jupyter
runtime:
    /home/<USER>/.local/share/jupyter/runtime

Some of these paths might not exist, so that you do not need to handle them. Others might have the actual configuration and data that you intend to use (in my case, this is the virtual environment at ./venv/).

Next, (re)move those directories that might contain outdated information, e.g.,

mv /home/<USER>/.jupyter /home/<USER>/.jupyter.bck # keep as a backup
sudo mv /usr/share/jupyter /usr/share/jupyter.bck

Moving the configuration directories resolved some peculiar but harmless warnings that I had. Moving the data directories resolved the 404 issue and allowed me to open my notebooks again. I did not touch the runtime directory.

Please let me know if this approach works for you; we can later update this answer to keep it for later reference.

The error message you're seeing is a 404 error, which means that the server cannot find the requested resource. In this case, the resource is the Jupyter notebook you're trying to open.

There are a few possible reasons why you might be seeing this error:

1. The notebook file is not in the correct location. Make sure that the notebook file is in the same directory as the Jupyter server.
2. The notebook file is not named correctly. Make sure that the notebook file has a `.ipynb` extension.
3. The Jupyter server is not configured correctly. Make sure that the Jupyter server is configured to serve notebooks from the correct directory.

To troubleshoot the issue, you can try the following:

1. Check the Jupyter server logs to see if there are any error messages that might indicate what's going wrong.
2. Try opening the notebook file in a different browser or on a different computer to see if the issue is specific to your environment.
3. Try renaming the notebook file to something else and see if that resolves the issue.

If none of these troubleshooting steps resolve the issue, you may want to try reinstalling Jupyter or seeking further assistance from a Jupyter expert.

**Answer:** The error message you're seeing is a 404 error, which means that the server cannot find the requested resource. To troubleshoot the issue, you can try checking the Jupyter server logs, opening the notebook file in a different browser or on a different computer, and renaming the notebook file. If none of these steps resolve the issue, you may want to try reinstalling Jupyter or seeking further assistance from a Jupyter expert.

Body:
After switching to Visual Studio Preview, I noticed a blue bar at the top of codespace, and clicking on it takes me to the first lines of the current file. The problem is that when I click on the highlighted links (CodeLens), the click seems to go to this area after moving to the definition and instead of displaying the definition of a method or class, I move to the first lines of the file in which this class or method is defined.

How can I disable this blue bar?
P.S. this has nothing to do with Unity, it also appears in projects on NET.8 and in C++ projects
Consistency_Inconsistent: [{"start":675,"end":828,"text":"\\n1. Place your cursor on the Navigation Bar.\\n2. Press `Ctrl + .` (dot) to open the Quick Actions menu.\\n3. Select **Disable Navigation Bar** from the menu.","labels":["Inconsistent (Number of Solutions)"]}]
GPT_Answer:
The blue bar you're referring to is called the "Navigation Bar" or "File Navigation Bar" in Visual Studio. It's a feature introduced in Visual Studio 2022 and later versions, including the Preview versions.

To disable the Navigation Bar in Visual Studio Community v17.13 Preview 1.0, follow these steps:

1. Open the Visual Studio Options dialog by pressing `Ctrl + Q` or by navigating to **Tools** > **Options**.
2. In the Options dialog, navigate to **Text Editor** > **General**.
3. Uncheck the box next to **Navigation Bar**.
4. Click **OK** to save the changes.

Alternatively, you can also use the **Quick Actions** feature to disable the Navigation Bar. To do this:

1. Place your cursor on the Navigation Bar.
2. Press `Ctrl + .` (dot) to open the Quick Actions menu.
3. Select **Disable Navigation Bar** from the menu.

By disabling the Navigation Bar, you should no longer see the blue bar at the top of your codespace, and clicking on CodeLens links should take you directly to the definition of the method or class without navigating to the first lines of the file.
Title: How turn-off Blue bar in on top of codespace in VisualStudio Community v17.13 Preview 1.0

AnswerContent:
The immediate problem is that the timer handler closure is not actor-isolated. We can solve that by adding MainActor.assumeIsolated {} (not, generally, Task { @MainActor in }).

There is a more subtle problem that is only evidenced when you change the Strict concurrency checking build setting to Complete, namely that the Timer parameter of the scheduledTimer closure is task isolated and this non-Sendable type cannot be updated from an actor-isolated context.

You can solve both of these problems by moving the Timer reference to an actor-isolated property in conjunction with assumeIsolated:

private var timer: Timer?              // main actor isolated property

func updateBuyAmountWithJsValue(url: String, delaySeconds: Double, maxTries: Int, js: String) {
    var tries = 0
        
    timer = Timer.scheduledTimer(withTimeInterval: delaySeconds, repeats: true) { _ in
        MainActor.assumeIsolated {     // let compiler know this is being called on main thread, and therefore can be isolated to main actor
            tries += 1
            if self.webView.url?.absoluteString != url || tries > maxTries {
                self.timer?.invalidate()
                return
            }
            self.webView.evaluateJavaScript(js) { result, error in
                if let error {
                    print("Error executing JavaScript: \(error)")
                } else if let value = result as? String {
                    if value.contains(".") || (tries==maxTries && value.count < 10) {
                        self.updateBuyProgress("AMOUNT*" + value)
                        self.timer?.invalidate()
                    }
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

There are other refinements I might suggest, but this illustrates the basic idea.

Alternatively, if you are willing to adopt Swift concurrency, it is simpler:

func updateBuyAmountWithJsValue(url: String, delaySeconds: TimeInterval, maxTries: Int, js: String) async throws {
    for _ in 0 ..< maxTries {
        try await Task.sleep(for: .seconds(delaySeconds))

        if webView.url?.absoluteString != url {
            return
        }

        if
            let value = try await webView.evaluateJavaScript(js) as? String,
            value.contains(".") || value.count < 10
        {
            updateBuyProgress("AMOUNT*" + value)
            return
        }
    }
}

Or you could use an AsyncTimerSequence, but the idea would be the same: Namely, retire the closure-based API and thereby eliminate all the issues those introduce in Swift concurrency (especially with Swift 6 and/or strict concurrency checking).

I have a fresh install of VS Code and am working to get my python interpreter set up. I prefer to run my code through the terminal line by line, so I have set python.REPL.sendToNativeREPL: false in settings.json. This successfully sends code to the terminal, but it seems to add additional indentation (see screenshot below), causing the error IndentationError: unexpected indent. For longer sections of code, it seems that an additional indent is added to the front of each new line. How can I address this issue?

I've searched for a relevant answer but can't find much regarding this setting online.

This happens because you have set `python.REPL.sendToNativeREPL` to `false` in your settings.json file.","labels":["Not Concise (Excess)"]},{"start":1328,"end":1568,"text":"**Step 4: Verify the solution**\\n\\nAfter applying one of the above solutions, try running your Python code through the terminal again. If the issue persists, you may need to try a combination of the above solutions or seek further assistance.\\n","labels":["Not Concise (Excess)"]}]
Consistency_Inconsistent: [{"start":652,"end":1326,"text":"To fix this issue, you can try one of the following solutions:\\n\\n* **Disable auto-indentation**: You can disable auto-indentation in VS Code by setting `\"editor.autoIndent\": false` in your settings.json file. This will prevent VS Code from adding extra indentation to your code.\\n* **Use a different terminal**: Try using a different terminal emulator, such as the built-in Terminal in VS Code or an external terminal like Git Bash. This may help resolve the issue.\\n* **Reset VS Code settings**: If none of the above solutions work, try resetting your VS Code settings to their default values. You can do this by deleting the `settings.json` file and restarting VS Code.","labels":["Inconsistent (Factual)","Inconsistent (Conceptual)","Inconsistent (Number of Solutions)"]}]
GPT_Answer:
**Step 1: Understand the issue**

The problem is that when you run your Python code through the terminal in VS Code, it adds extra indentation to the code, causing an IndentationError. This happens because you have set `python.REPL.sendToNativeREPL` to `false` in your settings.json file.

**Step 2: Identify the cause**

The extra indentation is likely due to the way VS Code handles code formatting when sending it to the terminal. When `python.REPL.sendToNativeREPL` is set to `false`, VS Code uses its own formatting rules to format the code before sending it to the terminal. This can lead to extra indentation being added.

**Step 3: Solution**

To fix this issue, you can try one of the following solutions:

*   **Disable auto-indentation**: You can disable auto-indentation in VS Code by setting `"editor.autoIndent": false` in your settings.json file. This will prevent VS Code from adding extra indentation to your code.
*   **Use a different terminal**: Try using a different terminal emulator, such as the built-in Terminal in VS Code or an external terminal like Git Bash. This may help resolve the issue.
*   **Reset VS Code settings**: If none of the above solutions work, try resetting your VS Code settings to their default values. You can do this by deleting the `settings.json` file and restarting VS Code.

**Step 4: Verify the solution**

After applying one of the above solutions, try running your Python code through the terminal again. If the issue persists, you may need to try a combination of the above solutions or seek further assistance.

**Conclusion**

By understanding the cause of the issue and applying one of the above solutions, you should be able to resolve the problem of extra indentation being added to your Python code when running it through the terminal in VS Code.
Title: VS Code Adds Indentation upon ctrl+enter with "python.REPL.sendToNativeREPL": false

AnswerContent:
The main issue is in this line result = cursor.execute("SELECT * FROM Students WHERE Firstname=? AND Lastname=?", (Firstname,Lastname)), which is why you're getting a cursor object. You don't need to assign the cursor.execute to a variable. We're only defining, inside the cursor object, which statement will be executed.

And then, in the next line, result.fetchone(), you forgot to get the results in a variable. See my suggestion below.

from flask import Flask, render_template, request, g

import sys
import sqlite3
import os

current_directory = os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route('/student')
def student():
    connection = sqlite3.connect(current_directory + "/sss.db")
    cursor = connection.cursor()
    Lastname='Volley'
    Firstname='Vlad'
    # we don't need to assign this to a variable
    cursor.execute("SELECT * FROM Students WHERE Firstname=? AND Lastname=?", (Firstname,Lastname))
    # now we get the results using the cursor object, which will execute the select statement
    result = cursor.fetchone()
    res = list(result)
    connection.commit()
    connection.close()
    return render_template('student.html', res=res)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.debug=True
    app.run(port=3000)
Body:
Here is my code in app.py from flask import Flask, render_template, request, g import sys import sqlite3 import os current_directory = os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__)) app = Flask(__name__) @app.route('/student') def student(): connection = sqlite3.connect(current_directory + "/sss.db") cursor = connection.cursor() Lastname='Volley' Firstname='Vlad' result = cursor.execute("SELECT * FROM Students WHERE Firstname=? AND Lastname=?", (Firstname,Lastname)) result.fetchone() res = list(result) connection.commit() connection.close() return render_template('student.html', res=res) if __name__ == "__main__": app.debug=True app.run(port=3000 ) Now in student html file I'm trying to display the data just to ensure its there but as you can see from the app file I'm converting the results from the query to a list so I can visualize it on the student html page butit always return a empty list and the data is in the sqlite3 database. Students HTML Code Snippet below:

Is this You?

{{res}}

Below is a image of my db file:
GPT_Answer:
The issue you're encountering is due to the way you're handling the result of your SQL query. When you execute a query using `cursor.execute()`, it returns the cursor object itself, not the results of the query. To get the results, you need to call one of the fetch methods on the cursor object, such as `fetchone()`, `fetchmany()`, or `fetchall()`.

In your code, you're calling `fetchone()` but not storing its result anywhere. Then, you're trying to convert the cursor object to a list, which is why you're getting an empty list.

Here's how you can modify your code to fix this:

```python
@app.route('/student')
def student():
    connection = sqlite3.connect(current_directory + "/sss.db")
    cursor = connection.cursor()
    Lastname='Volley'
    Firstname='Vlad'
    cursor.execute("SELECT * FROM Students WHERE Firstname=? AND Lastname=?", (Firstname,Lastname))
    res = cursor.fetchone()  # Store the result of fetchone() in the res variable
    connection.commit()
    connection.close()
    return render_template('student.html', res=res)
```

By doing this, `res` will hold the first row of the query result (or `None` if no rows were found). If you expect multiple rows, you should use `fetchall()` instead:

```python
res = cursor.fetchall()
```

This will give you a list of tuples, where each tuple represents a row in the result set.

Also, note that you don't need to call `connection.commit()` when only reading data from the database. `commit()` is used to save changes made to the database, but since you're only executing a SELECT query, there are no changes to commit.
Title: SQlite3 and Flask Select query returning a cursor object or a empty list instead of a tuple of values

Here's an example of how you can do this:","labels":["Inconsistent (Factual)","Inconsistent (Code)"]}]
GPT_Answer:
To allow variables in Monaco Editor for a Sass file, you can use the `monaco.languages.setMonarchTokensProvider` method to define a custom language configuration that recognizes Sass variables. Here's an example of how you can do this:

```javascript
monaco.languages.setMonarchTokensProvider('sass', {
  defaultToken: '',
  tokenPostfix: '.sass',
  keywords: [
    'var',
    // Add other Sass keywords here
  ],
  brackets: [
    ['{', '}'],
    ['[', ']'],
    ['(', ')']
  ],
  operators: [
    '+',
    '-',
    '*',
    '/',
    '%',
    '=',
    '==',
    '!=',
    '>',
    '<',
    '>=',
    '<=',
    '&&',
    '||',
    '!'
  ],
  // Define a rule for variables
  rules: [
    {
      token: 'variable',
      regex: '\\$[a-zA-Z_][a-zA-Z0-9_]*'
    },
    // Add other rules here
  ]
});
```

In this example, we define a custom language configuration for Sass that recognizes variables starting with a dollar sign (`$`) followed by one or more alphanumeric characters or underscores. We also define a rule for variables using the `token` property and a regular expression.

To use this configuration, you'll need to create a new instance of the Monaco editor and pass the language configuration to the `create` method:

```javascript
const editor = monaco.editor.create(document.getElementById('editor'), {
  value: [
    '$palette-secondary: #333;',
    'body {',
    '  background-color: $palette-secondary;',
    '}'
  ].join('\n'),
  language: 'sass',
  theme: 'vs-dark'
});
```

In this example, we create a new instance of the Monaco editor with a sample Sass code that uses a variable. The `language` property is set to `'sass'`, which tells Monaco to use the custom language configuration we defined earlier.

By using this custom language configuration, you should be able to use variables in your Sass code without getting errors in the Monaco editor.
Title: Allow $var in Monaco Editor for sass file

AnswerContent:
After moving the the compiler options specifically the baseUrl and paths in tsconfig.app.json, the module reference not found in TypeScript is now resolved.

It should be obvious to add the compiler options in tsconfig.TARGET.json since in the initialization of a Vite react-ts app, the tsconfig.json doesn't have any compilerOptions but instead references the other two tsconfigs.

tsconfig.json:


    {
      "files": [],
      "references": [
        { "path": "./tsconfig.app.json" },
        { "path": "./tsconfig.node.json" }
      ]
    }

tsconfig.app.json:


    {
      "compilerOptions": {
        "tsBuildInfoFile": "./node_modules/.tmp/tsconfig.app.tsbuildinfo",
        "target": "ES2020",
        "useDefineForClassFields": true,
        "lib": ["ES2020", "DOM", "DOM.Iterable"],
        "module": "ESNext",
        "skipLibCheck": true,
    
        "baseUrl": "./",
        "paths": {
          "@/*": ["./src/*"]
        },
    
        /* Bundler mode */
        "moduleResolution": "bundler",
        "allowImportingTsExtensions": true,
        "isolatedModules": true,
        "moduleDetection": "force",
        "noEmit": true,
        "jsx": "react-jsx",
    
        /* Linting */
        "strict": true,
        "noUnusedLocals": true,
        "noUnusedParameters": true,
        "noFallthroughCasesInSwitch": true,
        "noUncheckedSideEffectImports": true
      },
      "include": ["src"]
    }

the vite.config.ts remains the same as above.
